Article Machine learning-assisted screening of SA-FLP dual-active-site catalysts for the production of methanol from methane and water Tao Ban a b Jian-Wei Wang a Xi-Yang Yu b Hai-Kuo Tian b Xin Gao b Zheng-Qing Huang b Chun-Ran Chang b * a Key Laboratory of Coal Cleaning Conversion and Chemical Engineering Process, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830017, Xinjiang, China Key Laboratory of Coal Cleaning Conversion and Chemical Engineering Process School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Xinjiang University Xinjiang Urumqi 830017 China Key Laboratory of Coal Cleaning Conversion and Chemical Engineering Process, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830017, Xinjiang, China b Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Energy Chemical Process Intensification, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, Shaanxi, China Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Energy Chemical Process Intensification School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Xi’an Jiaotong University Xi’an Shaanxi 710049 China Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Energy Chemical Process Intensification, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, Shaanxi, China * Corresponding author. One-step direct production of methanol from methane and water (PMMW) under mild conditions is challenging in heterogeneous catalysis owing to the absence of highly effective catalysts. Herein, we designed a series of “Single-Atom” - “Frustrated Lewis Pair” (SA-FLP) dual active sites for the direct PMMW via density functional theory (DFT) calculations combined with a machine learning (ML) approach. The results indicate that the nine designed SA-FLP catalysts are capable of efficiently activate CH4 and H2O and facilitate the coupling of OH* and CH3* into methanol. The DFT-based microkinetic simulation (MKM) results indicate that CH3OH production on Co1-FLP and Pt1-FLP catalysts can reach the turnover frequencies (TOFs) of 1.01 × 10−3 s–1 and 8.80 × 10−4 s–1, respectively, which exceed the experimentally reported values by three orders of magnitude. ML results unveil that the gradient boosted regression model with 13 simple features could give satisfactory predictions for the TOFs of CH3OH production with RMSE and R 2 of 0.009 s–1 and 1.00, respectively. The ML-predicted MKM results indicate that four catalysts including V1-, Fe1-, Ti1-, and Mn1-FLP exhibit higher TOFs of CH3OH production than the value that the most relevant experiments reported, indicating that the four catalysts are also promising catalysts for the PMMW. This study not only develops a simple and efficient approach for design and screening SA-FLP catalysts but also provides mechanistic insights into the direct PMMW. Graphical Abstract This study designs SA-FLP dual-active-site catalysts for efficient CH4 and H2O conversion to CH3OH. Combining DFT and machine learning, Co1-FLP, Pt1-FLP, Fe1-FLP, Mn1-FLP, Ti1-FLP, and V1-FLP present outstanding catalytic performance. Keywords Single-atom catalyst Frustrated Lewis pair Machine learning Dual active sites Methanol synthesis 1 Introduction Methane, as the primary constituent of natural gas, has the potential to be upgraded into value-added chemicals or liquid fuels [ 1–3 ]. Currently, methane utilization technology is primarily based on indirect conversion methods that produce carbon monoxide and hydrogen, which is subsequently converted to value-added chemicals through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [ 4,5 ]. However, the reforming of methane to carbon monoxide and hydrogen is energy-intensive and cost-effective process. A promising alternative syngas stepwise process is the direct conversion of methane into methanol. Many expensive oxidants, such as SO3 [ 6 ], H2O2 [ 7,8 ], and N2O [ 9 ] have been explored in the direct conversion of methane to methanol, but they have not been amenable to commercial application due to high costs. The use of low-cost O2 as oxidants still suffers from unsatisfactory selectivity because of the favorable formation of CO2 [ 10,11 ]. To surmount this problem, it is promising to use water as the oxidant without molecular oxygen [ 12–14 ]. For example, Sushkevich et al. [ 12 ] reported the direct production of methanol from methane and water (PMMW), which shows high methanol selectivity (~97%) over a Cu-containing zeolite. Jeong and co-workers [ 13 ] used Cu(II)-exchanged zeolite for the continuous direct PMMW, and they found that the CO2 selectivity decreases at high Cu/Al ratios due to the preferential formation of the trimer. However, the direct PMMW is thermodynamically challenging under standard conditions (ΔG o 298 K = +117 kJ/mol), and the existing metal-doped zeolite systems often suffer from low yield of methanol. Hence, exploring alternative oxidants or development of more efficient catalysts for the PMMW is extremely urgent. The one-step PMMW at single oxides or other individual materials is very attractive [ 15–17 ]. In recent years, CeO2 has garnered considerable interest as a catalyst for methane conversion, driven by its exceptional ability to both release and store oxygen atoms [ 18,19 ]. Building on its ability to reversibly store and release oxygen, our group recently developed a new approach to create “Single-Atom” and “Frustrated-Lewis-Pair” (SA-FLP) dual active sites on transition metal (TM)-doped CeO2 (M@CeO2) by regulating surface oxygen vacancies (Vo) [ 20 ]. We have demonstrated that doped TM single-atom in CeO2 acts as an active site for CH4 activation. The FLP sites exhibit greater acidity and basicity than classical Lewis acid-base pairs, allowing them to function as additional active sites for activating other small molecules. Recent studies indicate that the FLP sites are crucial for the cleavage of the C–H bond during in methane activation [ 21 ], and promoting the reduction in strength of the C=O bond in CO2 [ 22,23 ]. Most recently, Zhang et al. [ 24 ] demonstrated that FLP effectively activate the H2O molecule. Thus, building on insights from previous studies, the use of SA-FLP dual active sites for catalyzing methane and water into methanol is imaginable. To rationally design more efficient M@CeO2 catalysts, it is necessary to fully understand the reaction mechanisms of the PMMW over the SA-FLP dual active sites. In the past, there have been several efforts endeavored to use conventional computational methods, such as density functional theory (DFT)-based microkinetic modeling (MKM) simulation, to improve the mechanistic understanding of this reaction [ 25,26 ], which is important for the further optimization of this catalytic system. However, both DFT calculation and MKM simulations are time-consuming due to the complexity of the methane oxidation to methanol reaction, especially in screening other M@CeO2 candidates. Recently, machine learning (ML) method has shown immense potential to guide the design and screening of catalyst properties [ 27–29 ], especially successful prediction of adsorption energies (E ads) for different reaction systems [ 30–33 ]. For instance, Toyao et al. [ 30 ] developed an extra tree regression (ETR) algorithm with 12 features to predict the E ads for reaction intermediate of the utilization of methane, such as CH x (x = 0, 1, 2, 3) on the Cu-based alloys. Zhu et al. [ 32 ] used XGBoost and ETR algorithms to predict the E ads for the reaction intermediate in the CO2 reduction process over the SA catalysts in zeolites. However, there are few reports on the reactivity prediction by using ML models, which can simplify the process for rational catalyst design before DFT calculations and trial experiments. Most of the previous data-driven methods are the prediction of DFT energies, and then an MKM of the proposed reaction path is simulated based on the DFT energies [ 34–36 ]. However, a comprehensive ML model, which can directly learn the results from the MKM of methane oxidation into methanol, has remained largely elusive. Therefore, it is promising to construct ML models by directly learning the physicochemical properties of the doped TM atoms and the production rates involved in a specific reaction network. In present study, nine SA-FLP dual active sites (Co1-, Rh1-, Ir1-, Ni1-, Pd1-, Pt1-, Cu1-, Ag1-, and Au1-FLP) were achieved by incorporating TM atoms onto the CeO2(110) surface and controlling the surface Vo. The adsorption and activation behaviors of CH4 and H2O were then systematically examined at SA and FLP sites, respectively. The reaction mechanism for the PMMW were thoroughly investigated by DFT and MKM calculations. Then, the methanol production rates over 16 new SA-FLP catalysts (Ti1-, V1-, Mn1-, Fe1-, Zn1-, Zr1-, Nb1-, Mo1-, Tc1-, Ru1-, Cd1-, Hf1-, Ta1-, W1-, Re1-, and Os1-FLP) were predicted by the trained ML models. This work aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism for the PMMW, while also establish a simple and reliable ML model to assist the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Computational details 2.1 DFT calculations The DFT calculations were conducted using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [ 37,38 ]. The core electrons were represented by the projected-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [ 39 ], while the exchange-correlation potential was treated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [ 40 ]. To localized Ce 4f electrons, the DFT + U method was applied (U = 4.5 eV) [ 21,41 ]. A kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV was applied for the plane-wave basis set. The van der Waals interactions were accounted for using DFT-D3 method with zero damping [ 42 ]. The structures were optimized until the force convergence to less than 0.02 eV/Å. For Brillouin zone sampling, the Monkhorst-Pack scheme was used, with a 7 × 7 × 7 k-point mesh for CeO2 bulk. The Γ point was applied for calculations involving the CeO2(110) surfaces. Transition state (TS) structures were searched using the nudged elastic band (NEB) method, followed by dimer method [ 43,44 ]. Each TS was confirmed by frequency analysis, with a single imaginary mode identified. 2.2 Microkinetic simulations Microkinetic simulations were carried out at temperatures ranging from 473–773 K using the CatMAP software [ 45 ]. The mean-field approximation was employed to calculate the TOFs for the elementary steps involved in the direct PMMW (Table S1). The thermodynamic properties of gas-phase molecules were evaluated using the ideal gas approximation, while those of adsorbed species were determined using the harmonic approximation. 2.3 Machine learning In this study, the machine learning models were developed and executed the scikit-learn code package [ 46 ]. The coefficient of determination in the whole data set (R 2) and root-mean-squared-error (RMSE) were used to measure the accuracy [ 47 ]. Tree-based ensemble methods, such as random forest regression (RFR) [ 48 ], decision tree regression (DTR) [ 49 ], gradient boosted regression (GBR) [ 50 ], ETR [ 51 ], were applied to capture the relationship between the descriptors and CH3OH TOFs. Additionally, support vector regression (SVR) [ 52 ], k-nearest neighbor (KNN) [ 53 ], ordinary linear regression (OLR), PLS regression, and the least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO) regression were employed for comparison [ 54 ]. The initial dataset consists of the TOFs of CH₃OH production data collected from the MKM of the reaction of CH4 and H2O to methanol for nine different transition metal catalysts. The temperature ranges from 473 to 673 K with an interval of 10 K, and the lg pressure ranges from –3 to 3 with an interval of 0.3. The dataset consists of 3969 samples, and the ratio used for training and testing splits is 80% for training and 20% for testing. Cross-validation (CV) with 10-fold was performed to verify the reliability of the model. The hyperparameters of these models, such as the maximum depth of the decision tree and the minimum sum of instance weights required to form a child node, were optimized through an exhaustive grid search combined with 5-fold cross-validation, implemented via scikit-learn’s Grid Search CV method. Additionally, we utilized nested cross-validation to ensure that the hyperparameter tuning did not bias the evaluation results [ 46 ], and the optimal hyperparameters are summarized in Table S2. 2.4 Surface models Our earlier studies have demonstrated that SA-FLP dual active sites can be effectively formed on CeO2(110) surface (Fig. 1 ) [ 20 ]. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the SA sites were constructed by doping the transition-metal (TM) atoms into CeO2(110) surface, and the FLP sites were designed by the regulation of surface Vo (Fig. 1(b)). In the present work, nine transition metals, such as Co, Rh, Ir, Ni, Pd, Pt, Cu, Ag, and Au were chosen to create SA sites on CeO2(110) surface by substituting Ce atoms with the transition metals (Fig. S1). The FLP site was created by removing an oxygen atom adjacent to the TM atom (Fig. S2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activation of H2O and CH4 on SA-FLP dual active sites 3.1.1 Selective activation of H2O on FLP sites The adsorption and activation behaviors of H2O were investigated at the SA and FLP sites, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 2(a) , H2O molecule adsorbs onto the SA site, with the E ads varying between –0.68 eV (Ir1-FLP) and –0.87 eV (Os1-FLP). On the SA sites, the adsorbed H2O molecule adopts a bent geometry, similar to that of gas-phase H2O molecules (Fig. 2(b) and Fig. S3). The charge density difference maps indicate minimal charge transfer between H2O and the SA site (Fig. S4), reflecting the weak van der Waals interactions involved in this process. Consequently, the O–H bond length of H2O increases from the gas-phase value of approximately 0.973 Å to around 1.00 Å upon adsorption (Table S3), demonstrating a slight elongation indicative of the weak interaction. In contrast, on FLP sites, the adsorbed H2O is dissociated to H* and OH* (* represents an adsorbed state), with the dissociated OH and H species binding to the FLP site via Ce−OH and O−H bonds, respectively (Fig. 2(b) and Fig. S5). The charge density difference maps reveal significant charge transfer during this process (Fig. S6), this strong interaction is reflected in the substantial elongation of the O−H bond length, which increases from the gas-phase value of 0.973 Å to approximately 1.74 Å upon adsorption (Table S3). The corresponding E ads at FLP sites varying between –1.16 eV (Ir1-FLP) and –1.36 eV (Au1-FLP). These results indicate that the FLP site can effectively activate H2O, while the H2O is only physisorbed at the SA sites. Hence, in the following study, the adsorption of H2O on the FLP site was taken into account. 3.1.2 The adsorption and activation of CH4 on SA sites With pre-activated H2O (Fig. 3 state 1), the adsorption and activation of CH4 on the nine SA-FLP dual active sites were then investigated. Our previous work demonstrated that CH4 shows a preference for adsorption at SA sites rather than FLP sites on the SA-FLP dual active sites [ 55 ]. Thus, we focus on the dissociation of CH4 at SA sites in this study. As shown in Fig. 3(a) and Fig. S7, the CH4 molecule adsorbs weakly on the SA site, with the E ads varying between –0.02 eV (Ag1-FLP) and –0.35 eV (Ir1-FLP), and the lengths of the C–H bond that points toward the surface remaining at approximately 1.10 Å (Fig. 3 state 2), which is consistent with the bond length observed in gas-phase (the C–H bond length of CH4 is 1.10 Å), indicating that CH4 is physisorbed on SA site. Afterward, the adsorbed CH4 is heterolytically dissociated to CH3* and H*, where CH3* binds to the SA site, and H* attaches to the adjacent O site. (Fig. 3 state 3). The activation energies for CH₄ activation on the nine SA-FLP sites vary between 0.76 and 1.16 eV, while the reaction energies vary between –0.87 and 0.85 eV. Among the nine SA-FLP catalysts, Pd1-FLP exhibits the best performance, with a reaction energy of 0.34 eV and an activation energy of 0.76 eV. 3.2 Conversion of CH4 and H2O to methanol After the co-adsorption of H2O and CH4, the conversion pathways for producing methanol from H2O and CH4 were further investigated. The reaction process on the nine SA-FLP catalysts involves eight steps as follows: (1) the dissociative activation of H2O into OH* and H* at the FLP site (state 0–1), (2) the adsorption of CH4 onto the SA site (state 1–2), (3) the heterolytic dissociative of CH4 (state 2–3), (4) the coupling of CH3* and OH* to form CH3OH* (state 3–4), (5) the desorption of CH3OH* from the surface (state 4, 5), (6) the migration of a proton from O site (Lewis base) to Vo (state 5, 6), (7) the formation of H2* via two protons, which subsequently adsorbs at the SA site (state 6, 7), and (8) the desorption of H2* from the surface (state 7, 8). The optimized structures and their corresponding energy profiles are shown in Fig. 4 , with additional structural details provided in Figs. S8–S16. The first three steps have been explored previously, i.e., H2O is activated to OH* and H* at the FLP site, and CH4 is activated to CH3* and H* at the TM site (state 0–3). The presence of OH* and CH3* on the surface increase the likelihood of C−O coupling to produce methanol (state 3, 4). It can be seen that except Rh1-FLP (reaction energy of 0.21 eV and activation energy of 1.07 eV) and Ir1-FLP (reaction energy of 0.23 eV and activation energy of 1.86 eV), the C–O coupling between CH3* and OH* to form CH3OH* on other seven SA-FLP catalysts is exothermic, with reaction energies ranging from –0.53 to –1.48 eV, and the corresponding activation energy spanning from 0.30 to 0.92 eV. These results suggest that the coupling of CH3* and OH* step is both kinetically and thermodynamically favorable on the majority of SA-FLP catalysts. Then, the next step is the desorption of CH3OH* from the surface (state 4, 5), except for Co1-FLP (1.25 eV) and Pt1-FLP (1.43 eV), the desorption energy of most SA-FLP catalysts span from 0.64 to 0.88 eV, suggesting that methanol can be readily desorbed from the surface. In the following step, the migration of a proton from O site (Lewis base) to Vo (state 5, 6), which requires overcoming activation energies from 2.31 to 2.95 eV, with reaction energies between 1.76 and 2.33 eV, indicating that this step is quite difficult. Then, the two protons form the H2* on the SA site (state 6, 7), which can easily occur with the highest energy barrier of 0.60 eV (Ir1-FLP). The last step of the reaction involves the release of H2 from the surface (state 7, 8), with the desorption energy varies slightly between 0.21 and 0.24 eV, except Au1-FLP (reaction energy of 0.50 eV), indicating that H2 is easily removed from the surface. Overall, the migration of H proton from the O site to the Vo site is identified as the rate-determining step of the whole reaction pathway. Among the nine SA-FLP catalysts, Co1-FLP shows the lowest activation energy (2.31 eV) on the migration of H proton from O site to Vo, indicative of Co1-FLP is the optimal catalyst for the PMMW. Additionally, to evaluate the stability of the nine SA-FLP catalysts, ab initio molecular dynamics simulations were performed, and the results indicate that they remain stable at high temperatures (Fig. S17). 3.3 Microkinetic modeling of the PMMW To gain insights into the entire reaction under realistic conditions, MKM based on the mean-field approximation were performed using the CatMAP [ 45 ]. In the microkinetic modeling, we made several key assumptions, including surface uniformity, treating all SA and FLP sites as identical and independent, simplifying the model. A steady-state approximation was used, assuming balanced intermediate formation and consumption, without accounting for transient effects like catalyst deactivation. The reaction pathway was simplified to focus on the main CH4 and H2O conversion, excluding side reactions that could influence selectivity. Lastly, gas-phase species were treated as ideal gases, minimizing non-ideal behavior at higher pressures. Details of the structure and formation energy are listed in Table S4. From Fig. 5 , one can see that the methanol production rate increases with rising temperature at a fixed pressure across the nine SA-FLP catalysts, while the production rate of methanol is not sensitive to the pressure. Across all nine SA-FLP catalysts, Co1-FLP and Pt1-FLP show higher TOFs of methanol production than the other seven SA-FLP catalysts. Under conditions of 673 K and 1 bar, the TOFs for CH3OH production on Co1-FLP and Pt1-FLP are 1.01 × 10−3 and 8.80 × 10−4 s–1 (Table S5), respectively, which are significantly higher than the value reported for most relevant catalysts (ranging from 7.53 × 10–7 to 1.74 × 10–6 s–1, as shown in Table S6) [ 13 ], indicating that Co1-FLP and Pt1-FLP are highly efficient and promising candidates for the PMMW. 3.4 Machine learning assisted prediction of the TOFs of CH3OH production ML-assisted prediction of TOFs of CH3OH production is carried out by following the five main steps. The first step is calculating the reaction energy and the activation energy for the elementary steps of the PMMW on the nine SA-FLP catalyst. The TOFs of CH3OH production data is then collected from the MKM of the reaction of CH4 and H2O to methanol, followed by using the collected CH3OH TOFs data to train the ML models based on the selected features. Lastly, the pre-trained ML models are used to predict new SA-FLP catalysts. 3.4.1 Feature selection The ML models are designed to capture the relationship between the TOFs of CH3OH production and 17 descriptors, including temperature (T), pressure (P), atomic number (N), group in periodic table (G), period in the periodic table (P r), atomic weight (A r), electron affinity (X), Pauling electronegativity (N m), atomic radius (R d), covalent radius (R c), first ionization energy (I m), second ionization energy (I m2), melting point (M p), density (ρ), molar volume (V m), thermal conductivity (T c), and heat capacity (C). All data are collected in the Table S7. The Pearson correlation coefficient matrix is used to identify the correlation between the descriptor pairs as shown in Fig. 6 . It is better that there is no linear relationship between features so that redundant parameters can be reduced. As shown in Fig. 6, the features of temperature and pressure have a low linear correlation (lower than 0.01) with all the others, indicating that they are independent. While the features of period and heat capacity have a high linear correlation (more than 0.80, in absolute value) with most of the others, suggesting that these features are highly correlated with other features. Thus, these two unnecessary features are excluded. After the initial screening, the number of primary features is reduced to 15, with most of the features are lower than 0.8 (in absolute value). 3.4.2 Performance of different ML models The TOFs of CH3OH production of the PMMW on the nine SA-FLP catalysts with the above-mentioned 15 features were used as input data to train the ML models. The RMSE and R 2 were selected to evaluate the performance of each ML model, and the results are presented in Table 1 . One can see that the R2 scores and RMSE of tree-based models (ETR, RFR, DTR, and GBR) on test set are 1.00 and 0.010–0.037 s–1, respectively, indicating that machine learning models created are accurate. In addition, non-tree-based models, such as SVM and KNN, also show rather good performance, with RMSE values on test set ranging from 0.037–0.072 s–1. However, these non-tree-based models were less accurate compared to the tree-based models. This is mainly because both SVM and KNN are more sensitive to high-dimensional feature spaces and may not handle complex interactions between features as effectively as tree-based models. Among these tree-based models, GBR exhibited the best performance on both the training set and the test set (Fig. 7 ). The RMSE values for the test set and the cross-validation set of the GBR model were 0.010 and 0.011 s–1, respectively, which are significantly lower than the RMSE of the other tree-based models (Table 1). The GBR model uses an ensemble of weaker models combined through boosting, providing a better balance between model complexity and predictive power. The GBR model ability to optimize for residual errors iteratively allowed it to capture more intricate dependencies between the descriptors and the TOFs of CH3OH production. Hence, the GBR model was selected to predict the TOFs of CH3OH production for SA-FLP catalysts in the subsequent discussion. After selecting the optimal ML model, the most important step is to understand the feature importance distributions for predicting TOFs of CH3OH production. The permutation feature importance in the GBR model for the most important features was identified in Fig. 8(a) . For predicting the TOFs of CH3OH production, temperature (T) and pressure (P) remain the most important or unimportant feature. This observation agrees with previous microkinetic modeling, which demonstrated that the TOFs of CH3OH production increases with rising temperature at a constant pressure, whereas the methanol production is not sensitive to pressure changes. This is because higher temperatures can enhance reaction kinetics by providing the energy needed for reactant activation, while pressure does not significantly affect the reaction pathway under the reaction conditions. Furthermore, both Pauling electronegativity (N m) and thermal conductivity (T c) are essential in defining the catalytic performance. N m affects the electron distribution around active sites, thereby affecting the activation of reactants. Transition metals with lower N m, such as Co, Ni, and Cu, tend to act as electron donors, transferring electrons to the CH4. This electron transfer enhances the polarization of the C–H bond, effectively reducing the activation energy required for bond cleavage. In contrast, transition metals with higher Nm, such as Pt and Au, prefer to retain their electron density, limiting electron transfer to CH4. This restriction results in less polarization of the C–H bond, leading to higher activation barriers. A notable exception is Pd, which, despite its relatively high electronegativity of 2.20 (comparable to Rh and Ir) (Table S7), exhibits the lowest activation energy for CH4 activation (0.76 eV) (Fig. 3(c)). This unique behavior can be attributed to its electronic structure, particularly its 4d orbitals, which are nearly fully filled but not completely. This configuration allows for optimal orbital overlap with the C–H bond, enabling strong interaction and effective polarization of the bond, thereby facilitating its cleavage. T c impacts the heat dissipation on the catalyst surface, which can also influence the reaction kinetics. In contrast, features such as group and density were found to have negligible contributions in predicting TOFs of CH3OH production. Thus, these two unnecessary features are excluded from the GBR model to improve its focus and efficiency. The ML models for the nine SA-FLP catalysts were re-trained using GBR with the above-mentioned 13 features, which include temperature, pressure, atomic number, atomic weight, electron affinity, Pauling electronegativity, atomic radius, covalent radius, first ionization energy, second ionization energy, melting point, molar volume, and thermal conductivity. The GBR model was re-trained using only the 13 features, and CV was performed to confirm the reliability of GBR model further. As illustrated in Fig. 8(b) and detailed in Table S8, the R 2 score and RMSE of the reduced GBR model are 1.00 and 0.009 s–1, respectively, which are similar to the GBR model with 15 features (R 2 = 1.00, RMSE = 0.0011 s–1). Although the number of features was reduced from 15 to 13, the accuracy of the GBR model, as evaluated by RMSE, was slightly improved compared to the preliminary model. Therefore, the re-trained models were utilized to predict the catalytic activities of the 16 unexplored SA-FLP catalysts. 3.4.3 ML-assisted prediction of TOFs of CH3OH production for screening other SA-FLP catalysts To further demonstrate the validity of ML models, the re-trained GBR model was used to screen other TM atoms for promising candidates with desirable TOFs of CH3OH production, such as Ti1-, V1-, Mn1-, Fe1-, Zn1-, Zr1-, Nb1-, Mo1-, Tc1-, Ru1-, Cd1-, Hf1-, Ta1-, W1-, Re1-, and Os1-FLP. All data are collected in Table S7. As shown in Fig. 9 , the production rate of CH3OH is basically unchanged with increasing pressure at a fixed temperature, while the production rate of CH3OH increases significantly with increasing temperature at a fixed pressure, indicating that the production of CH3OH is more sensitive to temperature, but not to pressure. This is in agreement with the trends at the nine SA-FLP catalysts calculated by DFT in Fig. 5, indicating the accuracy of the GBR model in predicting the rate of CH3OH production. Under conditions of 673 K and 1 bar, the CH3OH TOFs for the 16 unexplored SA-FLP catalysts ranged from 8.03 × 10−8 to 4.86 × 10−5 s–1 (Table S9). Importantly, the CH3OH TOFs for Fe1-FLP, Mn1-FLP, Ti1-FLP, and V1-FLP are ranged from 1.74 × 10−5 to 4.86× 10−5 s–1 (Table S9), which are significantly higher than the value reported for the most relevant catalysts, ranging from 7.53 × 10–7 to 1.74 × 10–6 s–1 (Table S6) [ 13 ], indicating that these four catalysts are also promising candidates for the PMMW. To further validate the superior catalytic abilities of as-predicted candidates, the Fe1-FLP was taken as an example to show the agreement between the mkm-simulated CH3OH TOFs and ML predicted CH3OH TOFs. First, the overall energy profile of the PMMW on Fe1-FLP was calculated by DFT calculation as displayed in Fig. S18(a), and the detailed structures are shown in Fig. S19. Then, microkinetic modeling is used to simulate CH3OH TOFs at the ML-selected Fe1-FLP catalyst (Fig. S18(b)). Lastly, the predicted CH3OH TOFs were obtained by the pre-trained GBR model (Fig. S18(c)). As shown in Figs. S18(b), (c), the predicted CH3OH TOFs and the mkm simulated TOFs show the same trend, i.e., the CH3OH TOFs increase with increasing temperature, while it is insensitive to changes in pressure. Under conditions of 673 K and 1 bar, the ML-predicted CH3OH TOFs on Fe1-FLP is 4.86 × 10−5 s–1 (Table S9), showing good agreement with the MKM-simulated values (4.47 × 10−5 s–1). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we developed a series of SA-FLP dual-active-site catalysts on TM-doped CeO2(110) surfaces for the PMMW. The main conclusions are summarized as follows. (1) DFT calculations demonstrate that the SA-FLP dual active sites are highly effective in activating CH4 and H2O into CH3* and OH* groups. Furthermore, the SA-FLP dual active sites facilitate the C−O coupling of CH3* and OH* to produce methanol. (2) Microkinetic simulations reveal that Co1-FLP and Pt1-FLP are efficient and promising catalysts for the PMMW with higher TOFs of CH3OH production than the most relevant catalysts reported. (3) The GBR model with 13 simple features could give satisfactory predictions for CH3OH TOFs (RMSE = 0.009 s–1, R 2 = 1.00). (4) Among the 16 predicted SA-FLP catalysts, four catalysts including V1-, Fe1-, Ti1-, and Mn1-FLP also exhibit higher TOFs of CH3OH production than the values reported in the most relevant catalysts, indicating that these four catalysts are also promising candidates for the PMMW. In addition, the promising nature of these catalysts highlights the value of dual-active-site strategies. Future research can focus on optimizing synthesis methods and exploring other transition metals in FLP configurations. This work presents a general strategy for screening dual active sites on metal oxide materials, and provides valuable insights into optimizing catalytic performance, setting a foundation for future advancements in catalyst development. coredata.dc:description: One-step direct production of methanol from methane and water (PMMW) under mild conditions is challenging in heterogeneous catalysis owing to the absence of highly effective catalysts. Herein, we designed a series of “Single-Atom” - “Frustrated Lewis Pair” (SA-FLP) dual active sites for the direct PMMW via density functional theory (DFT) calculations combined with a machine learning (ML) approach. The results indicate that the nine designed SA-FLP catalysts are capable of efficiently activate CH4 and H2O and facilitate the coupling of OH* and CH3* into methanol. The DFT-based microkinetic simulation (MKM) results indicate that CH3OH production on Co1-FLP and Pt1-FLP catalysts can reach the turnover frequencies (TOFs) of 1.01 × 10−3 s–1 and 8.80 × 10−4 s–1, respectively, which exceed the experimentally reported values by three orders of magnitude. ML results unveil that the gradient boosted regression model with 13 simple features could give satisfactory predictions for the TOFs of CH3OH production with RMSE and R 2 of 0.009 s–1 and 1.00, respectively. The ML-predicted MKM results indicate that four catalysts including V1-, Fe1-, Ti1-, and Mn1-FLP exhibit higher TOFs of CH3OH production than the value that the most relevant experiments reported, indicating that the four catalysts are also promising catalysts for the PMMW. This study not only develops a simple and efficient approach for design and screening SA-FLP catalysts but also provides mechanistic insights into the direct PMMW.
